newsitem.title: GERMANY: German coalition-SPD tax deal possible - Lafontaine.
newsitem.headline: German coalition-SPD tax deal possible - Lafontaine.

text.p: The leader of Germany's opposition Social Democrats Oskar Lafontaine said on Tuesday a tax agreement with the ruling coalition was possible and that the two sides would meet again on April 23.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Tuesday met with SPD leaders for more than three hours, but did not reach an agreement on a tax reform.
"We have the impression that we can reach an agreement, so we should try again," Lafontaine said.
Lafontaine said he saw compromise possible on five points. They include personal income tax cuts, tax allowances, child subsidies, reductions in corporate taxes and labour overheads.
The SPD wanted to cut by two percentage points the job insurance contributions deducted from employee paychecks. The coalition wanted a one point cut.
The reductions could be financed through a combination of increases in Germany's value-added and fuel oil taxes, Lafontaine said.
